the valleys of lower Bohemia,
where Cynthius with his radiant arrows,
even under the sign of Cancer, Leo or Virgo,
cannot whiten, wholly or in part,
those damp places, nor diminish
their beautiful color, green like Medean stone.

27. But in the happy season of Spring,
one must attend to the decorative, jewel-like
colors of stone, and work diligently
to create those patterns of
Emerald or Sapphire green, like a chessboard.
Further, in the center, the sinuous windings
of the murmuring streams crystalline as glass,
flowing between the grassy green banks

28. We should plant both sides
of these twisting brooks of Fish
with delicate sedge, reeds, and sword-like iris,
and refresh the still pools
that mirror the rough banks,
as the gentlest of Eolus’ messengers
and his lady love frolic happily
on the beautiful carpet of the Hinnides.
left-middleOn painting waters and their banks or shores with irises and greenery.
left-middleHinnides are Goddesses of the meadows, or marshlands, as Thomas Porcacchi attests.

29. Rivers overrunning their banks
should be shown wandering in these marshes;
take care that the water always moves toward the lowest point.
There beneath, to embolden Art,
building Sea-towns, stretching to high ground,
with Castles on Cliffs, difficult to destroy.
And then, climbing somewhat higher, let us nimbly
divide the outstretched Field into sections.
left-middleWater always going toward the lowest point; Castles on the Cliffs.

30. On one side, Ceres with her blond ears,
the other, the field still full of unripe oats;
there Eurus, to pass the time, comes sliding in,
making the field a Sea of green waves
with a gentle rustling murmur.
Here grows Vetch, there Buckwheat, and clover,
Red and blue flowers in the wheat,
And useful flax, the color of sky.
left-middleFields with their crops, blown by the wind.

31. Also, the plowed Fields, crossed with furrows,
or sometimes plains with harvested crops;
and again, meadows and Fields with ditches,
hedges and wandering paths.
Then some peculiar cluster
of Shepherds’ huts or Farmers’ cottages
in rocky caves, hollow trees,
or with walls and roofs raised on stilts.
left-middleOccasionally, plowed Fields, and paths, though one must be able to see where the paths begin and end.
left-middleOn unusual Farm-cottages and Shepherds’ huts.
